text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised CCDM 32.1.8, Regulation Handbook, Publishing the Final Regulation.
CCDM 32.1.8.4.4 is being revised regarding updating a Regulatory Identiﬁer Number after publication of a Treasury Decision.
This section supersedes CCDM 32.1.8, dated August 1, 2018.
Table of Contents
Final Regulation
) The IRS receives written and oral comments from the public about its and NPRMs (see CCDM
and CCDM
). Also, when TEMPs and NPRMs, section
(f) requires the IRS to solicit comments the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration (see CCDM
) The comments are analyzed to determine which, if any, comments are to adopted in the ﬁnal regulation. (

) After evaluating the comments, the IRS may ﬁnalize some NPRMs with any, change. However, some NPRM comments may identify new technical issues, policy considerations, or technical errors. Depending on the nature extent of the changes to be made, the drafting team may need to address issues, conduct additional legal research, or draft a new issues or policy memorandum. Sometimes another NPRM is issued because the regulation being re-proposed. (

) In general, the review procedures for ﬁnal regulations are the same as the cedures for NPRMs. Therefore, often the ﬁnal regulation project will be assigned to the attorneys and reviewers who worked on the NPRM. (

) All ﬁnal regulations must go through general circulation (“ green”), even if ﬁnal regulation is a no change TD. In general, the clearance chain of the signature package (“pink”) is the same for ﬁnal regulations as for NPRMs. However, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury signs ﬁnal and temporary regulations. See CCDM
) The preamble (see CCDM

) of the ﬁnal regulation summarizes the regulation (without describing the entire document), describes the posture of the regulation (e.g. the NPRM, and ANPRMs), discusses any ences between the rules contained in the NPRM and those adopted in the regulations, and explains the reason for the changes. The preamble to the regulations generally must address all comments and explain why each comment was adopted or why the comment was not adopted. The also must explain any other changes that were made to the contents of the regulation proposed in the NPRM. Pursuant to Code section
(f), the preamble must address any comments submitted by the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the SBA. See CCDM
and CCDM

) The IRS usually publishes one ﬁnal regulation with respect to the NRPM. Occasionally, Counsel and Treasury decide to — a. Issue several ﬁnal regulations with respect to one NPRM, b. Finalize part of the NPRM and withdraw the rest, or c. Finalize part of the NPRM and re-propose the rest.

) If the IRS plans to publish several ﬁnal regulations with respect to one the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation project retains the original CASE-MIS ID and RIN. Several Final publishing the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation, the drafting attorney must close the CASE-MIS ID using status code

(Closed - Publication). The drafting attorney should open a new CASE-MIS ID and obtain a new RIN for each sequent ﬁnal regulation project. In the CASE-MIS remarks screen for each subsequent ﬁnal regulation project, the drafting attorney should note the and original CASE-MIS ID of the underlying NPRM and all related ﬁnal tions. The drafting attorney should also enter this information in the remarks screen for the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation. (

) To publish ﬁnal regulations with respect to part of an NPRM and withdraw rest, the drafting team must prepare two documents — a ﬁnal regulation and Part of the notice of partial withdrawal of notice of proposed rulemaking. After publishing the ﬁnal regulation, the drafting attorney must close the CASE-MIS ID using status code
(Closed — Publication). (

) The IRS may publish a ﬁnal regulation with respect to part of an NPRM and re-propose the rest at the same or a later time. The ﬁnal regulation retains Part of the original CASE-MIS ID and RIN. After publishing the ﬁnal regulation, the attorney must close the original CASE-MIS ID using status code

(Closed — Publication). The drafting attorney must open a new CASE-MIS ID. In the CASE-MIS remarks screen for the new NPRM, the drafting attorney should note the name and original CASE-MIS ID of the ﬁrst NPRM project and the number of the ﬁnal regulations. The drafting attorney should enter the tion about the new NPRM in the remarks screen for the ﬁnal regulation. (

) By default, the RIN for the ﬁnal regulations will be closed when the ﬁnal lations are published. If the RIN is closed, a new RIN must be obtained for new NPRM project. Alternatively, the drafting attorney may contact the tions and Regulations Branch in Procedure and Administration and ask that status of the RIN for the ﬁnal regulation be updated to NPRM. (

) The IRS may decide to re-propose the NRRM in its entirety. The CASE-MIS and RIN are not closed. In this case, the re-proposed NPRM retains the the NPRM CASE-MIS ID and RIN that was originally issued. The original publication of the NPRM is withdrawn. A notice of withdrawal of the NPRM that was published is prepared and published in the Federal Register.

If the IRS plans to publish several ﬁnal regulations with respect to one NPRM, the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation project retains the original CASE-MIS ID and RIN. After publishing the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation, the drafting attorney must close the original CASE-MIS ID using status code

(Closed - Publication). The drafting attorney should open a new CASE-MIS ID and obtain a new RIN for each sub- sequent ﬁnal regulation project. In the CASE-MIS remarks screen for each subsequent ﬁnal regulation project, the drafting attorney should note the name and original CASE-MIS ID of the underlying NPRM and all related ﬁnal regula- tions. The drafting attorney should also enter this information in the remarks screen for the ﬁrst ﬁnal regulation.
the Final Regulation

) When the IRS publishes a ﬁnal regulation pursuant to a TEMP with cross- referencing NPRM, the ﬁnal regulation amends the CFR by codifying the Temporary underlying NPRM (with any changes) and withdrawing the temporary regula- with tion. Therefore, the ﬁnal regulation retains the RIN assigned to the NPRM. (

) To ensure that the temporary regulations are withdrawn from the CFR, the drafting team must write an amendatory instruction in the ﬁnal regulation Temporary “removes” the obsolete text of the temporary regulations from the CFR. (

) To ensure that the expired text of temporary regulations (“ sunset” temporary regulations) does not remain in the CFR indeﬁnitely, the drafting team must Temporary prepare an amendment to the CFR that “ removes” the text of the expired temporary regulations from the CFR. (

) To ensure that the IRS issues the ﬁnal regulation in compliance with Federal administrative and other requirements governing the regulations process, Regulatory drafting team must revise certain documents submitted for the NPRM (if cable), or prepare new ones, for the ﬁnal regulation.
